ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Furthered my Chinese speaking, listening, and writing ability greatly.
Continued study of speaking, reading and writing chinese.
I learned intermediate chinese
Increased my Chinese proficiency significantly. I thought I learned a lot in L1&2, this blew that out of the water
My speaking ability improved greatly.
I gained a deeper understanding of the patterns, grammar, and nuances used in Chinese.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course had an absurd amount of work, which didn't so much improve my Chinese as unnecessarily add to stress levels. I do not feel it was at all beneficial.

The course is very structured, which is a strong point. Maybe more assignments dedicated to just practicing writing would be helpful. Tere are definitely a lot of helpful resources available from the Chinese department.
Wonderful course! Wish there was a way character writing could be learned online and I did prefer Chinese class in person, but overall it was well organized and I learned a lot.
Professor Wang is an amazing.

Chinese 130 was an incredibly consistent course- I knew what to expect each week, and though the workload was very high, this level of consistency made it a bit easier to manage. I think the course could be improved with time to go over somewhat vague feedback with the instructor once in a while.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of quia and heavy use of Canvas both improved the online learning experience.
I think the class did the best it could with COVID, however I do think language classes particularly suffer from being online because they require engagement and it's easier to get distracted online.
Every day meetings were essential and super helpful. Would keep those for sure!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. In terms of my Chinese abilities, it was extremely helpful.
If you want to keep learning Chinese, this is a good class!
Yes!

Increased my Chinese proficiency significantly. I thought I learned a lot in L1&2, this blew that out of the water. Super straightforward what youll get out of this class. Want to continue learning Chinese? Take it. Its taught very well. World class Chinese education.
YES
